campaign.subject: How to respond to reviews (good and bad)
campaign.description: Best practices for responding to all types of reviews

slides.title: Review Responses

content.headline: Turn Reviews into Opportunities
content.subhead: How to respond to any review

slides.narration: Reviews are conversations with your customers—and everyone watching. How you respond matters as much as the review itself. Let's master review responses.

slides.title: What You'll Learn
slides.narration: We'll cover responding to positive reviews to encourage more, handling negative reviews professionally, timing and templates to save time, and how to turn negative situations into wins.

slides.title: Positive Reviews

content.example: Thanks Sarah! So glad you loved the seasonal menu. The butternut squash soup is our chef's favorite too. See you next time!

slides.narration: For positive reviews: thank them by name, reference something specific they mentioned, invite them back, and keep it brief. Example: 'Thanks Sarah! So glad you loved the seasonal menu. The butternut squash soup is our chef's favorite too. See you next time!' Personal, warm, brief.

slides.title: Negative Reviews

steps: Apologize - Even if not your fault

slides.narration: For negative reviews, use the HEARD framework. Hear: acknowledge their specific concern. Empathize: show you understand their frustration. Apologize: even if it's not entirely your fault, apologize for their experience. Resolve: offer a specific solution. Document: invite them to contact you directly to resolve.

slides.title: Response Timing
slides.narration: Timing matters. Within twenty-four hours is ideal—shows you're attentive. Within forty-eight hours is acceptable. Never ignore negative reviews—silence looks worse than the review. Batch your responses twice daily so it doesn't consume your day.

slides.title: What Not to Do

mistakes: Don't ask them to remove or change review

slides.narration: What not to do. Never argue or get defensive—you'll lose even if you're right. Don't make excuses—take responsibility. Avoid generic copy-paste responses—people can tell. Don't ask customers to remove or change reviews—it's against most platforms' policies and looks bad.

slides.title: Pro Tips

tips: Negative reviews with good responses often help you
Ask happy customers to review right after good experience
Monitor all platforms, not just Google
Use reviews as feedback to improve

slides.narration: Pro tips. Negative reviews with thoughtful responses often help you—people see how you handle problems. Ask happy customers to review right after a good experience—timing matters. Monitor all platforms, not just Google. Use reviews as genuine feedback to improve your business.

slides.title: Start Responding
slides.narration: Ready to respond? View your pending reviews and start applying what you learned. Or download our response templates for quick starting points you can customize. Every review is an opportunity.
